discussion.content: Reduce the remediation time during host patch or host upgrade operations.

questions.question_text: What is the benefit of using Allow Quick Boot during host updates on supported hardware?

A vSphere administrator has a requirement to add the identity source with the Integrated Windows Authentication option on vCenter Server with External Platform
Services Controller.
Which two conditions should be met to complete the task? (Choose two.)

choices.B: vCenter Server should be joined to AD Domain.
choices.D: External Platform Services Controller should be joined to AD Domain.
choices.C: External Platform Services Controller should be an appliance.
choices.E: vCenter Server must be in Enhanced Linked Mode configuration.
choices.A: Platform Services Controller must be able to reach the AD domain.

discussion.content:
I will go with B & D on this one

Reason: In order to completer the task both vCenter and PSC need to join AD.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.psc.doc/GUID-02C0861B-BC0D-4CDD-BF4E-53A60EF03B71.html#GUID-02C0861B-BC0D-4CDD-BF4E-53A60EF03B71
If you want to add an Active Directory identity source to Platform Services Controller, you must join the Platform Services Controller appliance to an Active Directory domain.

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.psc.doc/GUID-B23B1360-8838-4FF2-B074-71643C4CB040.html#GUID-B23B1360-8838-4FF2-B074-71643C4CB040
it said: If you are adding an Active Directory identity source, the vCenter Server Appliance or the vCenter Server Windows machine must be in the Active Directory domain

Choosing A & D seem misleading. My opinion is Answer D supersede A. I might be wrong but I strongly believe B & D is best suit for this question

I think this is A & D. The PSC is external, and it is that component that joins the domain, not the VC itself.

https://www.vembu.com/blog/active-directory-authentication-vsphere-6-7-update-1/

questions.question_text:
An administrator is planning a new cluster deployment supporting groups of 4 fault tolerant VMs. The fault tolerant systems require 8 vCPUs each.
What is the minimum number of hosts required to achieve this?

discussion.content:
B is correct. 4 hosts would only cover 1 group of VM's. Each VM within each group would require two vCPU's each to meet the requirement. 
das.maxftvmsperhost
The maximum number of fault tolerant VMs allowed on a host in the cluster. Both Primary VMs and Secondary VMs count toward this limit. The default value is 4.
das.maxftvcpusperhost
The maximum number of vCPUs aggregated across all fault tolerant VMs on a host. vCPUs from both Primary VMs and Secondary VMs count toward this limit. The default value is 8.

comments.content:
Me too but I think it will go like this. Pls correct me if i am wrong.

8vCPU is max per host meaning one host = one VM
1FT require 2VM (for thise case 2 hosts)
4FT require 8VMs (for this case 8 hosts)

discussion.content: Maximum number of FT VM's per host = 4, max number of vcpu's aggregated across all FT systems = 8. Question is confusing, but I think 8 hosts would be correct over 4, but I can't decide.

It asks what file, not what format. I would go with B:
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.html.hostclient.doc/GUID-38F4D574-ADE7-4B80-AEAB-7EC502A379F4.html
I think B is correct. SESparse is the FORMAT of the delta disk, but the actual file created is a -delta.vmdk file.

comments.content: C is correct becuse -delta.vmdk will be created regardless you use VMFS5 or VMFS6 but sesparse is specific to VMFS6.

discussion.content: "SEsparse is a default format for all delta disks on the VMFS6 datastores."
